title: Chapda Chutney
subtitle: Spicy red ant chutney
description: Known as Chapda, this fiery red ant chutney is a traditional delicacy of the Bastar tribes. Made from dried red ants and their eggs, it is rich in formic acid and believed to cure ailments like fever and cough. The sharp, tangy taste combined with local spices makes it unique.

title: Mahua Daru
subtitle: Traditional flower wine
description: Brewed from the fragrant flowers of the Mahua tree, this traditional wine is central to tribal culture. It is consumed during festivals, weddings, and social gatherings as a sacred community drink.

title: Mahua Gathering
subtitle: Forest produce livelihood
description: The collection of Mahua flowers is a seasonal activity involving entire families. Flowers are dried and stored for year-round use in food, liquor, and traditional medicine.

title: Chila
subtitle: Rice flour pancake
description: Chila is a simple pancake made from rice flour and water. It is commonly eaten for breakfast and is often served with chutney or forest vegetables.

title: Bore Basi
subtitle: Fermented rice meal
description: Bore Basi is a traditional dish made by soaking cooked rice overnight in water. It is eaten in the morning, especially during summers, and is known for keeping the body cool and improving digestion.

title: Pej
subtitle: Rice water drink
description: Pej is a light rice water drink prepared during rice cooking. It is nutritious, easy to digest, and commonly consumed by elders and children.

title: Kodo–Kutki Rice
subtitle: Nutritious millet meal
description: Kodo and Kutki are traditional millets grown by tribal communities. They are highly nutritious and used to prepare rice, porridge, and rotis.

title: Sukha Saag
subtitle: Dry forest greens
description: Sukha Saag is made from dried forest leafy vegetables. It is cooked with minimal spices and reflects the tribes’ deep knowledge of edible forest plants.
